review.title: UAVs using Bayesian Optimization to Locate WiFi Devices
review.abstract: We address the problem of localizing non-collaborative WiFi devices in a large region. Our main motive is to localize humans by localizing their WiFi devices, e.g. during search-and-rescue operations after a natural disaster. We use an active sensing approach that relies on Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) to collect signal-strength measurements at informative locations. The problem is challenging since the measurement is received at arbitrary times and they are received only when the UAV is in close proximity to the device. For these reasons, it is extremely important to make prudent decision with very few measurements. We use the Bayesian optimization approach based on Gaussian process (GP) regression. This approach works well for our application since GPs give reliable predictions with very few measurements while Bayesian optimization makes a judicious trade-off between exploration and exploitation. In field experiments conducted over a region of 1000 $\times$ 1000 $m^2$, we show that our approach reduces the search area to less than 100 meters around the WiFi device within 5 minutes only. Overall, our approach localizes the device in less than 15 minutes with an error of less than 20 meters.

metadata.title: UAVs using Bayesian Optimization to Locate WiFi Devices

sections.text: Our main motive is to locate people by locating their WiFi devices, e.g. during search and rescue operations after a natural disaster. We use an active sensor approach, which relies on Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) to capture signal strength measurements in informative places. It is difficult because the measurement is done at any time and they are only received when the drone is in the immediate vicinity of the device. Therefore, it is extremely important to make a prudent decision with very few measurements. We use the Bayesian optimization approach based on Gaussian process regression. This approach works well for our application, as GPS provides reliable prediction with very few measurements, while Bayesian optimization provides a reasonable compromise between exploration and exploitation. In field trials conducted over a region of 1000 x 1000 m2, we show that our approach reduces the search to less than 100 meters within 5 minutes of the device.

sections.heading: 2 Goals
sections.text: Our primary goal is to locate multiple WiFi devices in a particular region. To locate the device, the drone flies over region X in the hope of getting a measurement from the device. Measurements are received at random times. Let's assume that at the time t did not receive measurements with the timestamps t1, t2,... Note that the measurement t1 < t2 <. < tnt < t. sections.heading: 3 Data Characteristics and Challenges
sections.text: The main characteristics of our data is that the strength of the measurement is, on average, highest around the transmitter. Fig.2 shows the measurements collected from a laptop (Sony Vaio Pro-13 ultrabook) during an exhaustive scan of the region, which took more than 60 minutes. The device is located in the center of the image, and the size and color of the dots correspond to the signal strength. Unfortunately, locating the peak is a challenge due to the fact that the relationship between signal strength and distance is stochastical. This is because the measured signal strength is influenced by the noise, by the transmitter's performance, by the conversion of the receiver, and by the channel characteristics, which include reflection, multi-path scattering and shading. Therefore, at different distances, the distribution of the RSSI is different (whereby the measurements are heteroscedastic).

sections.heading: 4.1 Distribution computation using Gaussian Process Regression
sections.text: Gaussian process (GP) regression is one of the most popular choices within the Bayesian optimization framework =. It is also particularly suitable for our application for many reasons. First, GP regression is well in small-sample setting which is desirable in our setting since in the beginning of the search we don't have a lot of data. Second, GP regression is not only given predictions but also uncertainty associated with them, which helps us choose between exploration and exploitation (see below). Finally, hyperparameters of GP regression can be easily using maximum likelihood ation, so that easy implementation is possible (see end of this section).In this paper we use a regression model that gives us a Gaussian distribution at each candidate location x. In this paper we assume that the measurements are from a jointly Gaussian distribution.

sections.heading: 4.2 Deciding UAV’s Next Location using Bayesian Optimization
sections.text: We use the Bayesian optimization framework to determine the next location to visit. Decisions made on the basis of the distribution N (µ м | t, σ2 м | t) are intuitively based on the two competing objectives: 1. The drone should visit regions that resemble regions where high RSSI measurements have been observed. This is the exploitation step. 2. The drone should also visit unexplored regions that could potentially lead to high RSSI measurements. This is the exploration step. Bayesian optimization takes these two objectives into account by using a detection function Brochu et al. [2010]. In this paper, we use the detection function that measures the expected improvement compared to the location where the last highest RSSI measurement was observed. sections.heading: 4.3 Practical Issues
sections.text: Initialization by Quick Scan: During the initialization phase, the drone flies with a predetermined trajectory. Starting from the upper left corner of the search area, it reaches the opposite corner and bounces nine times from one edge to the other. The goal of this phase is to collect an initial number of measurements to start the Bayesian optimization algorithm. Stop Rule: The algorithm will stop if we do not improve our estimate. Specifically, we will stop if a few consecutive predictions lie within the same neighborhood of a predefined radius. Minor details on navigation: There are two small details about task 2 that are specifically tailored to our facility. First, the drone we used in our experiment does not travel exactly to the new predetermined location, but flies in a circle around that location with a predefined radius. However, the location where the measurements are received is xt, the actual position of the drone at the time. Second, after we have made a decision to fly to a new location during the V, decisions will not be made about the location of the flight.

sections.heading: 5 Details of UAV
sections.text: We can distinguish between two main types of small drones: rotary blades (i.e. multi-copters) and fixed wing sites. Multi-copters fly with the lift force generated by one or more blades (small drones typically have four blades, hence they are called quadricopters), they can take off and land vertically and hover in the air, but they are slow, particularly sensitive to the wind and therefore unsuitable to travel long distances. To cover a large search area, we chose fixed wing UAVs because they fly at higher speeds and higher energy efficiency than quadricopters. For the experiments, we used a rigid wing drone called eBee, developed by SenseFly SenseFly. The vehicle body is made of expanded polypropylene (EPP), and it has a single rear propeller disc driven by an electric motor.

sections.heading: 6.1 Hyperparameter Estimation for GP
sections.text: As discussed earlier, the selected hyperparameters are those that maximize the log probability protocol p (y | X, θ). They are l = 0.2, σ = 4.47 and σf = 3.32. To ensure that we do not match the data, we have tested the selected values against new measurements. Figure 6 (right) shows the MSE between new samples and the mean resulting from the selected hyperparameters. The left side of Figure 6 shows the log probability. We can clearly see that the hyperparameters that maximize the log probability also result in a very low value of MSE, which justifies the choice.

sections.heading: 6.2 Real-Data Based Simulations
sections.text: This section reports on simulation results based on real-world measurements. Our results indicate that the proposed method is capable of locating the device with an average error of 50 meters within 5 minutes. Specifically, we simulate the following: 1. sections.heading: 6.3 Real-World Experiments
sections.text: In this section we present the results of a field experiment. The WiFi device was a Samsung Galaxy Nexus i9250 smartphone, positioned in a square of 1000 x 1000 m2.The drone followed the trajectory shown in Figure 9. Figure 10 shows the localization error over time. We see that within 6 minutes the error is reduced to 50 meters, which confirms the simulation results. The entire flight lasted about 15 minutes, after that the localization error was 18 meters.Figure 11 shows the evolution of the averages and deviations of y, due to the measurements. From the same fiurements, we can also see whether the drone is in exploration or exploitation phases.After 5 minutes, the drone had collected only 7 measurements. The predicted mean value at that time was almost flat with a high deviation almost everywhere (see Figure 11 (a)).The star shows the estimated device position, while the other mariner predicts where we will determine the measurement direction of the next AV and the next 11.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusions
sections.text: In summary, both the field trials and the simulation results confirmed the effectiveness of the Bayesian optimization approach combined with GP regression to locate a non-collaborative WiFi device that emits very little PRF. Especially in the field trial, the estimate was within 18 meters of the actual device after 15 minutes.

sections.heading: A Appendix
sections.text: A.1 Expansion to Multiple Devices The sequential extension of the algorithm described in the previous section is simple. After locating the first device, the algorithm repeats the Bayesian search for each other target, while the initialization phase is performed only once at the beginning. To improve the localization of the first target, the UAV can potentially collect packets coming from any other target. Therefore, the algorithm has an advantage when estimating the position of the second target begins, as the dataset is already plentiful. To improve localization efficiency, we have designed a special variant of the algorithm to localize multiple devices. The idea is to fly the UAV in specific locations to collect measurements that may be useful for localizing all M devices. Let's define F as a set that contains the indices of the devices that have not yet been localized. After the initialization phase, F = {1, 2, M}.
